column15: English: A compilation of clips from various elder interviews. Nauciralrea Joseph Friday talks about the loss of Cup'ik culture in the future. Nauyaq Anna Andrew talks about the consequences of being a bad wife. Winifred Beans talks about encouraging people struggling with alcoholism to quit and traditional wisdom. An unidentified elder (maybe Jonathan Johnson) talks about the importance of using staffs while traveling and the importance of saving and spending money wisely. An unidentified elder (maybe Anesia Hoover) talks about suicide, alcohol abuse, and admonishing young people without making them feel bad. Aqesgirpak Mary Worm talks about seal hunters and a song for seal hunters, a supernatural dream, and people who do not follow traditional wisdom. Tuunralek Jimmy Chimegalrea talks about ancestors warning about the end of the world. And again Nauyaq Anna Andrew talks about being a child and staying out of trouble. Yugtun: Qalartuq yuut ayuqenrilameng ilait taringyuitniluki niicuitniluki-llu, qaneryaram maligtaqustai ak’anun anerteqtuniluki, ilameggnek-llu acivartesqevkenaki uputesqevkenaki-llu. Qalarrluni yurrluuvakaqaluneng aipaita unitelarciqniluki. Qalarrluni niicuilnguut taangaryulriit-llu piqaasqelluki, taangaryulriit uumikevkenaki tau͡gaam kenkesqelluki, enemeggni-llu taangangraata qimaasqevkenaki qaillun pinayukluki. Qalarrluni imarpigtellriani elegcingqerrlainaasqelluki ayarutun, aatami atii imarpimi nacecartullranek, nacessvini uscan elegcimikun anagyugngallranek, elegcigkun-llu malrurqugnek anirtuumallerminek. Qalarrluni atu’urkanun aki quyurtesqelluki, kemninarqellrianun akilluuqertellrianek, picurlagnarqucianek-llu. Qalarrluni ayagyuat ellmeggnek tuqutellrianek wall’u callualuteng tuqucilrianek, ellmeggnek pilriit assiilngurmun ellangarkauciantnek, irniateng-llu qaillun ayuqengraata qaruquraasqelluki. Qanemciluni ircenrraat kinguatni yugmek uurcamek, Elngum atii qasgimun aqumluni aturpagluni uurcaq ciuniutullruniluku, uurcaq tekicami negcikcuarani kapuarrluku qanemcitullranek, ciumeggni-llu ircenrraat amllertaciacetun tekitetullratnek. Mary Worm-aq qanemciluni qavamikun angalkurtellerminek. Qanemciluni ellam iqulitarkaanek niitetullerminek, cam iliiniku piitnamek qantullratnek, umyuaqelgurikeni pitekluku ellam iquklitlerkaanek aaryuuciminek. Qanemciluni ellminek atrartessiyaatullerminek, nasaurlullgutni ilalillrunritlerminek, akusrartellrianun ilautellruniluciminek, yuilqumi ellu’urtatullerminek equgtatullerminek-llu, assiitellriit atuusqevkenaki.

column15: English: A compilation of clips from various interviews and talks. An unidentified elder advises listeners against consuming alcohol. Cimiciaq talks about treating sores with medicinal plants. Ackiar Nick Lupie talks about rain gear, digging a hollow in the snow to sleep in, his experience almost suffocating sleeping in a snow hollow, people not knowing who they are related to across villages anymore, bird hunting in the spring when he was a boy, and animal food sources depleting because they are not revered anymore. An unideintifed elder talks about how ancestors used to be and some of their wisdom passed onto him. Cikiraq Jane Green talks about rosewort, vole caches, eating sticklebacks, and her son tending his wound with rosewort. An unidentified elder talks about lessons her parents taught her and seal oil as a medicine for sore throats and coughs. An undifentified elder, maybe Margaret Smart or Bell, talks about alcohol and marijuana affecting people. Kumangulria Matthew Bean talks about ice and flooding probability. Billy Lincoln Sr. talks about travelling to winter camp and multiple families staying in the same house. Paniguaq Peter Jacob talks about a supernatural experience with his dog. Ayaprun James Peter Sr. talks about the importance of memorizing the landscape. Mumess'aq Peter John talks about drinking urine as a survival tactic to stay warm if you're freezing. column15: English: Interview with elder Nauyaq Anna Andrew about her earliest memories. She talks about growing up in Tagyaraq and Quuneq. column15: A compilation of interviews and talks with elders. An unidentified elder talks about hunting muskrats, the shaman Qupanuaq, and sleepwalking. Uliggaq Martha Oscar Sara talks about the snow when she was growing up and preparations for spring camp. Narull'aq Narullgiar Elena Nick talks about her daughters and how youg girls learn chores from their mothers. Kumkaq Noel Polty talks about helping others, saving food, and the importance of knowing the geography of the land.

Qalarrluni tukangcaryaram qanruytainek, nallutailuciatnek, allat takuatni takairuyuciatnek nep’nguciatnek-llu, taangam aipaqellrianun navguutngucianek, taangam aturtainun ikayuqengnaquciatnek, imumi nepailuciatnek, assirlutek-llu aipaqucaramek.

column15: A roundtable discussion with elders Kelucaq Joe Andrew and Urutaq Lucy Beaver about the importance of loving and helping others in your community. They give examples like providing others with your extra food, mending their clothes, and helping build community houses in other villages. They talk about child birth, raising children, and teaching them traditional wisdom when they start becoming aware. They talk about the Boy Who Lived With Seals, the tradition of giving water to seals after they have been hunted, and the Bladder Festival, and how this practice was stopped after the priests came. They talk about not killing birds that are mothers so their chicks do not grow up without them. They talk about using bear saliva on the face and hands when hunting, and the importance of KYUK giving elders broadcast time to pass down traditional wisdom to younger generations.
